title: Search for Dark Matter Induced Airglow in Planetary Atmospheres
authors: Carlos Blanco, Rebecca K. Leane, Marianne Moore, Joshua Tong
abstract:
We point out that dark matter can illuminate planetary skies via ultraviolet
airglow. Dark matter annihilation products can excite molecular hydrogen, which
then deexcites to produce ultraviolet emission in the Lyman and Werner bands.
We search for this new effect by analyzing nightside ultraviolet radiation data
from Voyager 1, Voyager 2, and New Horizons flybys of Neptune, Uranus, Saturn,
and Jupiter. Our findings set new constraints on the dark matter-nucleon
scattering cross section down to about $10^{-40}~$cm$^2$. We highlight that
future ultraviolet airglow measurements of Solar System planets or other worlds
provide a new dark matter discovery avenue.
